text: Demand not that events should happen as you wish; but wish them to happen as they do happen, and you will go on well.
author: Epictetus

text: Let death and exile, and all other things which appear terrible, be daily before your eyes, but death chiefly; and you will never entertain an abject thought, nor too eagerly covet anything.
author: Epictetus

text: As a mark is not set up for the sake of missing the aim, so neither does the nature of evil exist in the world.
author: Epictetus

text: If a person had delivered up your body to some passer-by, you would certainly be angry. And do you feel no shame in delivering up your own mind to any reviler, to be disconcerted and confounded?
author: Epictetus

text: Begin by prescribing to yourself some character and demeanor, such as you may preserve both alone and in company.
author: Epictetus

text: Let not your laughter be loud, frequent, or abundant.
author: Epictetus

text: Avoid taking oaths, if possible, altogether; at any rate, so far as you are able.
author: Epictetus

text: Provide things relating to the body no further than absolute need requires, as meat, drink, clothing, house, retinue. But cut off everything that looks toward show and luxury.
author: Epictetus

text: Be not prompt or ready to attend private recitations; but if you do attend, preserve your gravity and dignity, and yet avoid making yourself disagreeable.
author: Epictetus

text: If you have assumed any character beyond your strength, you have both demeaned yourself ill in that and quitted one which you might have supported.
author: Epictetus

text: Conduct me, Zeus, and thou, O Destiny, Wherever your decrees have fixed my lot. I follow cheerfully; and, did I not, Wicked and wretched, I must follow still.
author: Epictetus

text: Who’er yields properly to Fate is deemed Wise among men, and knows the laws of Heaven.
author: Epictetus

text: O Crito, if it thus pleases the gods, thus let it be.
author: Epictetus

text: Anytus and Melitus may kill me indeed; but hurt me they cannot.
author: Epictetus

text: What truly lies within your control, and what must you accept as beyond it, in the realm of your own existence and function?
How can you distinguish between striving for greatness and being sidetracked by desires that might compromise the very freedom you seek?
How can you reshape your desires and aversions to align only with what is within your control, freeing yourself from the tyranny of disappointment and wretchedness?
How will you hold what you love without letting its loss break you?
How do you maintain your core purpose when external conditions disrupt your intended actions?
How might you shift from blaming external events to examining the internal perceptions that shape your reality?
Do you derive your worth from what you possess, or from how you engage with existence itself?
If the captain of your life calls, are you ready to abandon everything you've gathered on shore and run to the ship without looking back?
Is a broken body the breaking of the will, or merely an invitation to discover what within you remains unassailable?
What inner strength can you cultivate from each challenge you face, so that no external circumstance can ever overwhelm you?
When you lose something dear, can you see it not as a deprivation but as a return of what was never truly yours?
How can you distinguish between the fears that protect your survival and those that merely imprison your peace?
What if the frustration of a small inconvenience is simply the unavoidable cost of inner peace?
How do you define true improvement when it demands sacrificing external validation for inner alignment?
If your freedom depends on controlling what is not yours, can you ever truly be free, or are you simply choosing a master to serve?
How will you act when life's offerings come your way—not with craving or rejection, but with true choice?
How can you empathize with another's suffering while holding firm to the belief that their pain arises not from the event itself, but from their own judgment of it?
How will you embody the role you've been cast in, regardless of its length or nature, knowing that your only true power lies in the quality of your performance?
How can you transform every sign, no matter how ominous, into a source of strength and advantage for yourself?
Is freedom found in refusing the wars you cannot win, or in redefining what it means to conquer?
How might you reframe the perception of an external provocation to recognize it as a product of your own interpretation, thereby reclaiming control over your response?
Will you persist in your true convictions when mocked by the crowd, or be swayed into abandoning them, earning only greater ridicule?
How can you remain true to your inner philosophy when the temptation to seek external validation threatens to compromise your integrity?
How can you be of true consequence if you measure your worth by what lies outside your control?
What price are you unwilling to pay for what you envy in others, and what freedom have you preserved by refusing that price?
How might your own suffering transform if you viewed it with the same detached acceptance you readily grant to the misfortunes of others?
Before pursuing any goal, have you fully weighed all its hidden costs and sacrifices to ensure your ambition is not just a fleeting imitation?
How will you define and uphold your duties in any relationship, regardless of how others fulfill their roles?
How can you align your desires with the nature of things to avoid blaming the gods for what lies beyond your control?
When faced with uncertainty, how do you discern between seeking external guidance and trusting the internal principles that define your purpose?
When should silence prevail over speech, and how can you ensure your words always serve a purpose that elevates rather than merely echoes the ordinary?
How will you maintain your integrity when surrounded by influences that threaten to erode it?
How will you balance the demand for personal integrity with the necessity for compassion towards those who fall short, when your own righteousness becomes a silent accusation?
How would you respond to criticism that only highlights a fraction of your limitations, and what does that reveal about the flaws you know remain unseen?
How can you engage with the spectacle of the world fully present yet internally unchanged, observing outcomes without being defined by them?
How would you embody the composure of Socrates or Zeno when engaging with someone who seems your superior?
How will you maintain your inner purpose when the doors of power remain closed and your presence goes unnoticed?
How can you discern the delicate balance between self-expression and social propriety, ensuring your presence elevates others without diminishing your own integrity?
When faced with a tempting pleasure, will you choose the fleeting satisfaction of today or the lasting victory of knowing you judged yourself worthy tomorrow?
When should you trust your own judgment over the criticism of others, and how do you know your judgment is truly right?
When feasting with another, how do you reconcile the necessity of sustenance with the imperative of courtesy, and why might that very tension reveal the deeper values guiding your choices?
How can you guard the ruling faculty of your mind in every action, as carefully as you would watch each step to avoid stumbling or harm?
What is the proper measure of your own function, and how will you recognize the point where enhancement becomes excess?
How might the perception of women shift if their worth was measured not by the pleasure they provide, but by the integrity and dignity they embody?
How will you ensure that your pursuit of physical or sensory optimization does not become the very distraction that diminishes your capacity for reason?
Why must you endure harm gracefully instead of challenging the false assumptions that allow it?
Which handle will you choose to lift the situation—the one that weighs you down with judgment or the one that raises it with connection?
If you are not defined by your possessions or abilities, what truly constitutes your worth?
Can you truly judge an action without first discerning the intentions behind it?
How can your silence and actions demonstrate more truth than your words ever could?
How might you practice discipline in silence, letting your actions speak for themselves rather than seeking recognition?
How might you cultivate a self so resilient that external judgments become mere echoes, and your inner compass alone guides your response to the world?
If understanding Chrysippus only makes you a scholar of his words, what would make you a philosopher who lives them?
Why delay becoming who you ought to be, if not now, when?
Why do you spend more effort proving the rule than living by it?
